newsitem.title: CHINA: Kinkel says China, Germany set friendly course.
newsitem.headline: Kinkel says China, Germany set friendly course.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Tuesday that China and Germany had put their differences behind them and had set a new course for expanded economic ties.

Kinkel met Communist Party leader and State President Jiang Zemin and Premier Li Peng earlier in the day to cap a fence-mending trip long delayed by a diplomatic dispute over China's restive Himalayan region of Tibet.

China's leaders had made clear the dispute was now firmly in the past, Kinkel told a news conference after his meetings in the Zhongnanhai compound, central residence and workplace of China's communist leaders.
"Both sides see the misunderstandings as resolved. President Jiang used the words: 'after the rain the sky cleared quickly'," Kinkel said.
The prospects for Sino-German diplomatic ties and economic relations looked promising, he said.
Kinkel, who arrived on Monday for a five-day visit, said he had discussed human rights with Chinese leaders and had raised the cases of dissidents Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng.
Kinkel said Wang's family had appealed for him to mention the former student leader, currently awaiting trial on the capital charge of plotting to overthrow the government.
Wei Jingsheng, a veteran dissident, was sentenced to 14 years in prison last December for plotting to subvert the government.
The dialogue with Chinese officials on human rights had been non-confrontational, Kinkel said without giving details.

Kinkel had originally planned to visit in July, but Beijing withdrew its invitation after the German lower house of parliament passed a resolution accusing China of trying to eradicate Tibet's cultural identity.
The dispute briefly threatened to affect China's economic ties with Germany, Beijing's largest European trade partner.
Kinkel said Tibet had been discussed. He said differences remained between Beijing and Bonn over the issue, but gave no details.
"We have talked about this in our dialogue, and there are different opinions remaining," he said.
China's Xinhua news agency said Kinkel had assured Jiang that Germany would not interfere in Beijing's internal affairs and would maintain its stance that Tibet was part of China.
Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told a regular news briefing that foreign countries should not use differences over human rights to interfere in China's domestic concerns.
German opposition politicians have long criticised Kinkel's policies on China, accusing him of treading too softly on human rights to protect business opportunities for German industry.
About two dozen representatives of German companies, many of them specialising in environmental protection technology, have accompanied the foreign minister to China.
Asked about the case of Wang Dan, a leader of 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing that were crushed by the army, Kinkel said he was doing what he could.
"I raised a number of cases," he said. "I do what I can and I am aware of responsibilities in that respect."
Kinkel's main task in China was to lay the ground for German President Roman Herzog's state visit from November 18 to 25, Xinhua quoted Jiang as saying.
"President Roman Herzog's visit to China is an important event in bilateral relations," Jiang said.
Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen has accepted an invitation to visit Germany in early 1997.
